advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.atarihq.com/tsr/">ITSR'S NES ARCHIVE</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>A pretty secretary, a clean office with nice colours, and a computer working without any printer, cables, disks... Does it really sound realistic to you ?!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 1000 ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1991)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This japanese advert indicates that there were at least 3 different models sold...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST SDK-85 AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the Intel logo. Does Intel copies the Apple logo or vice versa?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT SEPT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> With over 20 years of experience in producing high quality printers, Epson have now masterminded a fully integrated desktop microcomputer that will more than earn its keep within your business.<br> The QX-IO is capable of performing all the tasks you will ever require of it, quickly and efficiently. Installation of the QX-IO can be carried out with the minimum of interruption, and with its easily understandable keyboard, it is simplicity itself to operate. Having such a diverse range of software packages available such as database from Pearl and office productivity and accountancy from Peachtree with CP/M and multifont BASIC as standard, the QX-IO can supply all the answers whatever your business.<br> Just look at what's on offer: a big memory - 192k upgradable to 256k RAM and all the graphics you'll ever need - and high resolution graphics at that.<br> The ability to communicate easily with other machines, including our own HX-20 and the advantage of using our fine range of printers, make the QX-lO a totally versatile system at a price you'll find impossible to equal.<br> £1735 plus VAT.<br> If you're looking at micros, look at the QX-IO. The system with all the answers. </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  ACORN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> This attractive package inherits the traditions of the famous Model B BBC microcomputer which is used by children in almost every school in the United Kingdom as well as colleges, hospitals, laboratories, factories, offices, banks and shops. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first advert for the Atari 520ST checked against an Apple Mac and an Apricot computer. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bradley Sturch</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The new ASC8000-6 single board computer is packed with ultra-high technology: Z80 double density computer, up to 2048Kb of high speed RAM, Floppy-disk and Winchester Hard Disk controllers, DMA, up to 6 serial / 2 parallel I/O, optional 32 bit floating point processor... All on one board, fully socketed, fully documented, reliable and maintainable...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IEEE INTERFACE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> The Acorn IEEE interface enables full implementation of the IEEE standard 488-1978. IEEE488 is also known, and is equivalent to IEC625-1 (in Europe), and GPIB or HP-IB (Hewlett Packard General Purpose Interface Bus)...<br> ...The interface can support a network of up to 14 other IEEE-488 compatible devices. Devices can be interconnected in a star or linear fashion. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>English advert for the 86A model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the 16K static RAM expansion is more expensive than the computer itself.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMTEXT BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> When you buy, lease or rent word processing equipment from AM Jacquard Systems, you get our total commitment, now and in the future, that assures the successful installation and operation of your AMtext word processing system. <br><br> To support that commitment, we have offices in over 100 cities throughout North America staffed with skilled professionals ready to meet your neads with planning, training. supplies, and service... <br><br> ...The AMtext 100 is a true shared resource, multifunction information system capable of supporting multiple work stations and peripherals simultaneously. <br><br> The Amtext 425 and 425A are powerful stand-alone work stations with a full-page video display <br><br> The AMtext 225 is a low-cost system that turns electric typewriters into flexible text editors. <br><br> The AMtext product line includes a complete selection of peripheral devices, including telecommunications, an optical character reader. magnetic card reader, phototypesetters, daisy wheel printers. high-speed line and matrix printers, as well as mass storage on floppy and hard disk drive units. <br><br></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
Though different in shape, the Soundic SD-290 is internaly the same system as the Rollet Video-Color, the Hanimex HMG-7900 and the Soundicvision SD-200. This SD-290 model was sold worldwide through different brands (in France for example by ITMC and Jou?Club)...
All these systems were surely produced by Soundic in Hong-Kong as they have code-names like "SD-2xx" (where SD would mean Soundic) on their electronic boards. These SD-2xx systems were not very powerful as even the Videopac systems were better... 5 years earlier!!
What is strange about these consoles, is that there are not clones of famous systems... The only system which is quite close in many points, though more powerful, is the japanese Cassette Vision from Epoch. The games plastic boxes are the same and the blocky graphics are very similar...
The Soundic SD-290 is square shaped, the case is white and blue colored with orange buttons and controls. It was delivered with only one controller which connects to the left side of the system. There is a second connector (on the right side of the system) for a second player controller, but as all the games were for one player only, it was never used. The controller can be stored in its compartment located on the top of the console. It is composed of a 4-directions disc on which can be screwed a little stick. There is also a knob for Breakout-type games and an orange fire button.
The control panel is made of three buttons and an on/off switch. The buttons are RESET, GAME SELECT and GAME START. GAME SELECT is used to select the different levels and options of the game.
The cartridge slot, protected by a trap door, is made of 22 pins and is placed at the top-left part of the console, just above the joystick storage compartment. Like on the HMG-7900, the case is labeled "Programmable Color Video Game". Inside, the main chipset is a NEC D779C 300. Nothing is known about this one... can you help please?
The games are very simple and cover the great classics such as Space Invaders, Breakout, Missile Command or Pac-Man (delivered with the system). But graphics, even in 8 colors, are poor. Concerning the PAC-MAN cover for example, all you can see is squares running after a cross... wow, that is almost virtual reality!
There was a total of 11 cartridges produced, though 5 more cartridges, for two players this time, were planned but never released (someone can confirm this?). These cartridges were: Football, Ski, Ice-skating (!), Car-Race and Tennis.
computer.keyboard: One controller with a joystick mounted on a 4-drections disk, one fire button and a knob for breakout-type games
computer.name: SD-290 Programmable Colour Video Game
computer.ports: Two controller connectors, cartidge slot, power in, RF TV output

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> SD-290</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://paleoinformatica.blogspot.com/2006/06/soundic-sd-290-os-pongo-las-fotos-de.html" target="_blank">Diario de un coleccionista informático</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BOX</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://paleoinformatica.blogspot.com/2006/06/soundic-sd-290-os-pongo-las-fotos-de.html" target="_blank">Diario de un coleccionista informático</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
